question: Objectives of ANC include all except -
exp: parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd edition *objectives of atenatal care are:(1)to promote protect and maintain the health of the mother during pregnancy. (2)to detect high risk cases and give thembspecial attention. (3)to foresee complications and pevent them. (4)to remove anxiety and dread associated with delivery. (5)to reduce maternal and infant moality and morbidity. (6)to teach the mother elements of child care, nutrition, personal hygiene and enviornment sanitation. (7)to sensitise the mother to the need for family planning including advice to cases seeking, termination of pregnancy. (8)to attend to the under five accompaning the mother.
opa: To attend to the under-fives accompanying the mother

question: The guidelines according to Baby Friendly Hospital Initiative includes all except -
exp: The global BFHI has listed ten steps which the hospital must fulfill. Have a written breastfeeding policy that is routinely communicated to all health care staff Train all health care staff in skills necessary to implement this policy Inform all pregnant women about the benefits and management of breastfeeding Help mothers initiate breastfeeding with in one half hour of bih. Show mothers, how to breastfeed and maintain lactation even if they should be separated from their infants Give newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk not even sip of water unless medically indicated. Practice room -in-that is allow mothers and infants to remain together 24 hours a day. Encourage breastfeeding on demand. Give no aificial teats or pacifiers to breast feeding infants Foster the establishment of breastfeeding suppo groups and refer mothers to them on discharge from the hospital or clinic. (refer pgno: 540 park 23 rd edition)
opa: Mothers and infant to be together for 24 hours a day
opb: Mother to initiate breast feeding within 4 hours of normal delivery
opc: Giving newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk

question: The most effective step in MCH is -
exp: The objectives of MCH care are- 1. Reduction of morbidity and moality rates of mothers and children 2. Promotion of reproductive health 3. Promotion of the physical and psychological development of child within family This is achieved by working under the following sub components- 1. Maternal health 2. Family planning 3. Child health 4. School health 5. Handicapped children 6. Care of children in special settings such as day care centres It is evident from the objectives and Sub components that the most effective step is maternal health promotion. Factors that effect maternal health such as urbanisation, rural migration, changing patterns of women&; s work and status is seen to have direct effect on child bearing and child rearing. Thus by achieving maternal health, it is possible to assure the achievement of all other steps. Hence option 1 is the most appropriate answer. Reference Park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd edition pg 555
opd: Non formal education of the mother

question: A community has a population of 10, 000 and a bih rate of 36 per 1000. 5 maternal deaths were repoed in current year the MMR is -

question: Component of PQLI -
exp: PQLI- Physical Quality of Life Index is one index to measure quality of life. It consolidates 3 indicators -infant moality rate -life expectancy at age one -literacy For each component score 0 to 100 given. The composite index is calculated by averaging three indicators, giving equal weight to each. Resulting PQLI is also scaled 0 to 100. Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine. K Park. Edition 23. Pg no: 17

question: High risk pregnancy are all except
exp: High risk pregnancy cases include: 1. Elderly primi (30yrs and more) 2. Sho statured primi (140cm and less) 3. Malpresentations such as breech, transverse lie etc. 4. Antepaum haemorrhage, threatened aboion 5. Preeclampsia and eclampsia 6. Anemia 7. Twins, hydraminos 8. Previous still bih, intrauterine death, manual removal of placenta 9. Elderly grandmultiparas 10. Prolonged pregnancy (14 days after expected date of delivery) 11. History of previous caesarean or instrumental delivery 12. Pregnancy associated with general diseases like cardiovascular diseases, kidney disease, diabetes, TB, liver disease, malaria, convulsions, asthma, HIV, I, STI ect. 13. Treatment for infeility 14. Three or more spontaneous consecutive aboions The only exception to the question is option 3 as veex presentation is not a case of high risk pregnancy. Reference: Park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd edition pg 526

exp: Family planning is not a component of RCH-II. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICAL 21. ST EDITION. PAGE NO - 411

question: Neonatal period is-
exp: Neonatal period is from bih to 28 completed days of life. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICINE. Editon-21. Page no.-521

question: MMR is a -
exp: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd edition. *Maternal moality ratio is defined as (total no of female deaths due to complications of pregnancy, childbih or within 42 days of delivery from puerperal causes in an area during a given year /total no of live bihs in the same area and year)x1000.

question: In ICDS the requirement in pregnant females is -
exp: The aim is to supplement nutritional intake as follows Each child 6-72 months of age to get 500 calories and 12-15 grams of protein Severlely malnourished child 6-72 months to get 800 calories and 20-25 grams protein Each pregnant and nursing women to get 600 calories and 18-20 grams of protein (refer pgno: 591 park 23rd edition)

question: Present in human milk
exp: Ref: Park's Text book of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th ed

question: Most common causes of perinatal moality?
exp: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd edition. *Preterm complications 35%, intrapaum complications 24%, sepsis 15%, congenital anomalies 10%, pneumonia 5%.

question: About Maternal moality rate which of the following is true?
exp: Maternal moality rate is the total no. of female deaths due to complications of pregnancy, childbih, or eithin 42 days of delivery from puerperal causes in an area during a given year divided by total no. of live bihs in the same area and year. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICINE. Editon-21. Page no.-514
opb: Numerator includes complications related deaths up to 42 days after pregnancy
opc: Denominator includes still bih and aboions
opd: Expressed as rate per 1000 live bihs

question: Maternal moality refers to maternal deaths from causes related to or aggravated by pregnancy and its management during -
exp: Maternal moality rate is total no. of female deatha due to complications of pregnancy, childbih or within 42 days of delivery from puerperal causes. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICINE. Editon-21. Page no.-514
opa: Pregnancy, child bih or first seven days after delivery
opb: Child bih or first foueen days after delivery
opd: Pregnancy, child bih or first 42 days after delivery

question: Best indicator for growth measurement is -
exp: Weight is the most sensitive measure of growth. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICAL 21. ST EDITION. PAGE NO - 502

question: MCH care is assessed by -
exp: The commonly used indicators of MCH care are: Maternal moality rate Moality in infancy and childhood: perinatal moality rate, neonatal moality rate, post-neonatal moality rate, infant moality rate, 1-4 year moality rate, under 5 moality rate, child survival rate. Reference: Park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd Edition

question: Maternal moility rate is -
exp: Maternal moality rati= maternal death/ 1000 live bih. Reference: Park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine, K. Park, 23rd edition, page no: 557. <\p>

question: According to school health services recommendations, a school should have -
exp: Provides and urinal should be provided, one urinal for 60 students and one latrine for 100 students. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICAL 21. ST EDITION. PAGE NO - 534
opa: 1 urinal\/ 60 children and 1 privy for 100 children
opb: 1 urinal\/ 80 children and 1 privy for 150 children
opc: 1 urinal\/ 100 children and 1 privy for 100 children
opd: 1 urinal\/ 100 children and 1 privy for 200 children

question: Whic of the following is categorised as a high risk pregnancy?
exp: High risk cases include: Elderly primi (>30years) Sho statured primi (<140cm) Malpresentations Antepaum haemorrhage, threatened aboion Pre-eclampsia and eclampsia anemia Twins Previous still bih, Intrauterine death, manual removal of placenta elderly grandmultiparas prolonged pregnancy history of caesarean or instrumental delivery Pregnancy associated with general diseases Treatment for infeility Three or more consecutive spontaneous aboions

question: Acute malnutrition is manifested by -
exp: Acute malnutrition is manifested by reduced weight for height. Weight reflect only the present health status. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICAL 21. ST EDITION. PAGE NO - 501

question: Child rights are guaranteed in which aicle of the constitution -
exp: parks textbook of peventive and social medicine 23rd edition. *relevant aicles for the right of child are: aicle 24 prohibits employment of children below the age of 14 in factories aicle 39 prrevents abuse of children of tender age aicle 45 provides for free and compulsory education for all children until they complete the age of 14years.

question: Human milk with respect to cow milk has -
exp: Fat in human milk-3. 4g and in cows milk-4. 1g per 100grams. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICINE. Editon-21. Page no.-582 table 21

question: Cow's milk contains what % proteins -
exp: Cow milk contain 3. 2%of protein. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICAL 21. ST EDITION. PAGE NO - 582

question: Compared with cow's milk, mother's milk has more -
exp: Lactose content in cows milk-4. 4g, breast milk-7. 4g per 100grams. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICINE. Editon-21. Page no.-582 table 21

question: Dose of iron and folic acid in pregrnancy is -
exp: During pregnancy, 100 mg iron and 500 mcg FA should be given. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICAL 21. ST EDITION. PAGE NO - 594

question: The socioeconomic status of community is best indicated by -
exp: Infant Moality Rate is the ratio of infant deaths registered in a given year to the total number of live bihs in same year, expressed as rate per 1000 live bihs. IMR is universally regarded as not only as the most impoant indicator of health status of community but also as the level of living of people and effectiveness of. MCH services in paicular. Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine. K Park. Edition 23. Pg no: 567

question: Most common cause of death in the age group of 1-4 years children is -
exp: Most common cause of death of children in age group of 1-4yrs is infections. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICAL 21. ST EDITION. PAGE NO - 527

question: Who are NOT benificaiaries of ICDS scheme -
exp: parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd edition * major beneficiaries of ICDS are pregnant women, nursing mothers, other women 15-45years, children less than 3years, children in age group 3-6years, adolescent girls11-18years.

question: Maternal moality is reduced to -
exp: In 2008, a global reduction in maternal death to 200 is estimated. REF. PARK'S TEXTBOOK OF PREVENTIVE AND SOCIAL MEDICINE. Editon-21. Page no.-515.

question: The best parameter for assessment of chronic malnutrition is -
exp: parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd edition * height is a stable measurement of growth as opposed to body weight. whereas the weight reflects only the present health status of the child, height indicate the events in the past also. *low height for age also knownn as nutritional stunting or drawfting. it reflects past or chronic mal nutrition.

question: A 14 year old boy having lost his father a year ago, is caught shoplifting. The boy will be sent to -
exp: parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rd edition * in remand homes, the child is placed under the care of doctors, psychiatrists and other trained personnel. every effos is made to improve mental and physical well beiing of the child. elementary schooling is given, various as and crafts are taught, gaames are played and other recreational activites are arranged. *boys over16years who are too difficult to be handled in a ceified school or have misbehavedvthere are sent to brostal.
